entry.title: Star Wars Outlaws PC system requirements – minimum and recommended
entry.summary:
The Star Wars Outlaws PC system requirements are officially out, and we know you'll need at least 16GB of RAM to run this massive game. The storage required for Star Wars Outlaws, however, might be less than you'd expect; Ubisoft definitely used some Jedi mind tricks.
Image via Ubisoft
Star Wars Outlaws PC system requirements for minimum specs
To play this game from a galaxy far, far away at 1080p on low settings, you'll need at least 65GB of SSD storage space and some decent specs. Here is everything you'll require, according to the Epic Games Store:
OS: Windows 10 with DirectX12
Processor: AMD Ryzen 5 3600 or Intel Core i7-8700k
Memory: 16GB (dual-channel mode)
Storage: 65GB SSD
Graphics: AMD Radeon RX 5600 XT (6GB), NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1660 (6GB) or Intel Arc A750 (8GB) with REBAR ON
This will let you play the game at 30 frames per second on the low preset with the upscaler set to quality. You'll also require a Ubisoft account for Star Wars Outlaws to run on PC. Unfortunately, the game isn't on Steam as of the time of writing.
Recommended specs for Star Wars Outlaws
If you're hoping to play Star Wars Outlaws as how the developers intended, you'll need the following specs:
OS: Windows 10 with DirectX12
Processor: AMD Ryzen 5 5600x or Intel Core i5-10400
Memory: 16GB (dual-channel mode)
Storage: 65GB SSD
Graphics: AMD RX 6700XT (12GB), NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3060Ti (8GB)
These specs will let you play Star Wars Outlaws at 1080p with 60 frames per second. You'll have the high preset with the upscaler set to quality.
As games finally begin to be developed for current-gen consoles and PC rather than relying on the older generation, we're seeing higher graphics quality in modern gaming. Black Myth: Wukong, another game releasing in August, requires 16GB of RAM as well rather than the typical 8GB.

entry.title: How to get Cattail Fluff in Fields of Mistria
entry.summary:
There’s a lot of crafting resources in Fields of Mistria, and some of them are easier to find than others. Unlike Wood, Stone, or even Hay, Cattail Fluff doesn’t come to you in the course of your everyday tasks, so where do you get it?
Where to find Cattail Fluff in Fields of Mistria
If you’re looking for Cattail Fluff, you’ll need to head to the Eastern Road. This area is east of Mistria on the map, and also the location of the bridge where you begin your Mistrian adventure and later repair.
Image by Destructoid
Cattail Fluffs can be found in the ponds and lakes towards the southern half of the Eastern Road map. Just like Water Chestnuts, they grow on the very edge of the water. They appear as Reeds, and when interacted with will produce the same amount of Cattail Fluff as there are heads on the Reeds.
Screenshot by Destructoid
Cattail Fluff respawns daily, so make sure to visit the area regularly to build up a hoard for all your crafting purposes. Alternatively, if you have a surplus of Tesserae, you can always buy Cattail Fluff from Balor's Wagon for 25 Tesserae each.
How to use Cattail Fluff in Fields of Mistria
Screenshot by Destructoid
When you’ve got a bunch of Cattail Fluff stocked up, you can head to your nearest Crafting Bench. There’s one in town outside the Bell Tower, and another at the Carpenters Shop, or you can purchase one to have on your farm from the latter as well.
Cattail Fluff is used to make any furniture with padding. This includes beds, chairs, and rugs. You’ll need a varying amount, depending on which item you’re wanting to craft, with the minimum amount being three in order to make a Worn Bed.

entry.title: A Quiet Place: The Road Ahead is releasing this October
entry.summary:
We've still a bit to go until the Halloween season is upon us. But now seems like a good opportunity for horror fans to get a wee bit excited. Along with Bloober Team finally getting ready to launch the remake of Silent Hill 2, Saber Interactive has also given us the launch date for A Quiet Place: The Road Ahead.
In the most recent trailer, we're being told that the horror adaptation will be coming to us on October 17. That's just a couple of weeks before the Spooky Season, which is always a bit of a cliché, but it does make sense.
The trailer itself is chock-full of the usual teases and snippets of gameplay. I certainly don't want to get ahead of myself given the general reputation of video game movie tie-ins, but The Road Ahead does look like it has a lot of potential.
To quietly go
Taking A Quiet Place's concept of remaining silent so as not to be detected by monsters should – on paper at least – translate well to the gaming sphere. Anyone who's ever played a survival horror game where the object is to avoid combat and enemy encounters knows all too well how tense things can get.
As for The Road Ahead itself, it's not a straight-up adaptation of the films. It boasts its own storyline inspired by its cinematic counterpart, although a previous trailer shows there may be some story elements that have been lifted from the first movie.
In any case, I don't want to immediately get my hopes up, but I can only contain any vague sense of excitement for so long. I am but human, after all.

The upcoming action RPG from Game Science, Black Myth: Wukong, features realistic graphics and intense gameplay. So, you must be intrigued to know the minimum and recommended PC requirements for the title, and here's everything you need to know.
Black Myth: Wukong is a Sekiro-like game that is based on Chinese Mythology, and is also one of the most anticipated games of August 2024, alongside Star Wars Outlaws.

Black Myth: Wukong minimum system requirements
These are the minimum PC requirements to play Black Myth: Wukong at 1080p in at least 30 frames per second:
OS: Windows 10 64-bit
CPU: Intel Core i5-8400 / AMD Ryzen 5 1600
Memory: 16 GB RAM
GPU/Graphics Card: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 6GB / AMD Radeon RX 580 8GB
DirectX: Version 11
Storage: 130 GB available space
Thankfully, the minimum specs aren't too demanding, unlike some other games that were released this year. This means if your rig is equipped with dated hardware, you'd still be able to enjoy the Sekiro-like at playable framerates.
If your system meets these requirements, an HDD would be enough to run the game, however, the devs always recommend an SSD for optimal loading speeds.

CPU: Intel Core i7-9700 / AMD Ryzen 5 5500
Memory: 16 GB RAM
GPU/Graphics Card: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2060 / AMD Radeon RX 5700 XT / INTEL Arc A750

entry.title: How to get Water Chestnuts in Fields of Mistria

Where to find Water Chestnuts in Fields of Mistria
You can get Water Chestnuts in Fields of Mistria by the edge of the water at the Narrows. The Narrows are to the left of the main Mistria location, on the same pathway as the Museum and Mines. The Water Chestnuts primarily spawn in the river at the bottom.
Screenshot by Destructoid
To harvest Water Chestnuts, look for small green sprouts in the water and approach them closely. Alternatively, you can jump into the river and swim around to collect them more efficiently.
Screenshot by Destructoid
You'll find a plentiful supply of Water Chestnuts in the river, making it easy to complete missions like Request for Water Chestnuts. Additionally, this ingredient can be combined with Wild Berries to make the Trail Mix recipe, a meal that's perfect for newcomers. It replenishes health and stamina by 12, which will undoubtedly be helpful when you're stuck in the mines. Fortunately, the Wild Berries are much easier to find, as they can be picked from bushes throughout the map.
To collect more Water Chestnuts in Fields of Mistria, you'll need to wait for them to respawn near the bridge. The chestnuts should be replenished daily, so keep checking on them in the Narrows.

entry.title: How to get Shards in Fields of Mistria

If you've begun the Shards Request mission, you'll likely be puzzled by the resource's mysterious locations. They aren't exactly out in the open like other items, given that they must be unearthed with specific tools. Where to find Shards and Dig Sites in Fields of Mistria
Use your shovel on a Dig Site to get Shards in the Fields of Mistria. If you haven't obtained this tool yet, the General Store sells a Worn Shovel for 500 Tesserae. I've had the most luck finding the Shards at the Western Ruins site, located to the left of the Narrows.

One Dig Site will spawn at the Western Ruins daily, so check back on this destination for more Shards. If you want to increase the digging spots there, speak to Caldarus (the dragon statue) and unlock the Western Ruins Scholar perk. It will spawn an additional spot to farm more resources.
Shards may appear in other areas, like the mines, whenever there's a Dig Site to uncover. I haven't had much luck outside of the Western Ruins, but it could still be possible. entry.title: Review: One Piece Odyssey (Switch) - A Safe But Solid Caper For The Straw Hats
entry.summary: Here be dragons. A couple of years ago, it was notable when the Switch remakes of Pokemon Diamond and Pearl were developed not in-house by Game Freak, but by a smaller Japanese support studio called ILCA. That remake project was actually ILCA’s first crack at being the lead developer on a game, and it soon followed this up early last year with One Piece Odyssey, an original JRPG based on the long-running franchise about wacky pirates. Now this release has finally made its way over to the Switch, and we’re happy to report that it’s made the jump almost entirely intact. Though it’s taken a bit of a visual hit, One Piece Odyssey still proves to be an enjoyable and accessible release that's a welcome addition to the Switch’s considerable RPG library. The narrative in One Piece Odyssey is a sort of ‘bottle episode’ that follows the adventures of the Straw Hat Pirates crew after they shipwreck upon a mysterious island called Waford. Shortly after arriving, a mysterious figure takes away their power (cutely represented by everyone dropping from level 40 down to 1) and locks it away in various magical cubes scattered across the island. Even when they recover some of the cubes, the only way they can unlock the power contained within is through diving into illusory worlds crafted from their memories and reconquering trials they once faced, although events play out a little differently this time around because of how ‘fuzzy’ memory can be. The crew thus sets out through worlds based on the memories of some of their greatest struggles to reclaim their power and get to the bottom of what’s going on with this strange island. entry.title: Virtuální Bastlírna vol. 41: Kosmické novinky
entry.summary:
Horka polevila, ale žár nadšení Strahováků z techniky nepolevuje! Za poslední měsíc se stalo několik událostí doslova kosmického charakteru. Došlo k úspěšnému startu a vypuštění sond z rakety Ariane 6, Boeing vyslal Starliner na oběžnou dráhu, kde nyní jeho pasažéři neplánovaně už druhý měsíc setrvávají. KiCAD má novou verzi a blíží se konference k jeho dalšímu vývoji. Objevil se nový čip kombinující RP2040 s ethernetem a povedlo se na čipu vytvořit pulzní safírové lasery. Jsou vám tyto novinky málo? Pak jsou na Virtuální Bastlírnu připravená i obecnější hardwarová témata!
Za HW lze probrat zajímavé nově objevené parazitní jevy v SiC MOSFETech, jak se dá operační zesilovač "zaseknout" nebo k čemu jsou dobré ztrátové koaxiální kabely a kde je sehnat. Samozřejmě bastlíři narazili i na kuriozity, například doutnavkovou logiku nebo plošňák, jehož součástí je ohýbačka na THT součástky.
Software ani tentokrát nezůstane stranou - kromě již zmíněné nové verze KiCADu se dá podívat na stavbu linuxového managovaného switche, NanoKVM, převod videa z DisplayPortu na eink nebo emulátor NESu na Picopadu.
Jak je zvykem, s postupem večera se jistě přejde i k lehce bizarním tématům - kupříkladu, co provedl CrowdStrike, jak zprovoznit Doom na erotických hračkách pro pány, jak vypadá nestandardní 12V USB nebo jak se ztrácí některé části audio záznamů z CD, protože je většina SW neumí správně přečíst.
Příští Virtuální Bastlírna se pod taktovkou projektu MacGyver studentského klubu SiliconHill bude konat ve středu 7. srpna od 20:00 minimálně do 22:00 (ale obvykle končí o dost později). Odkaz na konferenci se před samotnou akcí objeví na bastlířské wiki.

I've never learned to drive, but every so often a well-meaning friend tells me I'd be good at it, because 'look, Edwin, you play all those driving games, surely they've taught you the basics'. Friend, here is what driving games have taught me: traffic lights are there for regional flavour; drifting is the same thing as cornering; other cars exist to serve as bumper cushions when overshooting a turn. Certainly, nobody wants a guy whose ideas about automobiles come from 2018's Wreckfest to be involved in the school run. On which note: THQ Nordic have just announced Wreckfest 2 - a fresh helping of destruction derby with fancified visuals and newly animate drivers who flinch and gesticulate when other drivers smash into them. entry.title: Gothic Remake gameplay overview reveals an eccentric open world RPG that still feels like the future
entry.summary:
It's a hell of a thing to showcase a remake weeks after kiboshing the developers of the original game. In early July, Gothic creators Piranha Bytes were reportedly shuttered as part of Embracer Group's mad race to trim costs, following their decade-long acquisition binge. Watching THQ Nordic's new Gothic Remake trailer, below, feels a little like watching a vivisectionist parade about in somebody else's skin. Still, the remake's developers Alkimia Interactive aren't to blame for Embracer's fuck-ups, and I am selfishly happy to see Gothic return as an Unreal Engine 5 production - even if I didn't play the original back in 2001.
Sin did play the original game, and in her 2016 retrospective, she paints an absorbing picture of a dark fantasy "microsociety" in which every community "has a reason to exist, a means of providing for itself, a social order, and a long term goal". It's a setup that reminds me of my beloved Roadwarden, even as the sight of grumpy lizards slinking through undergrowth has me silently mouthing "fus roh dah".

entry.title: Titan Quest 2 sure looks like that brighter, breezier action-RPG you Diablo 4 haters were gunning for

Titan Quest 2! Now there's a name you can set your watch by. No colons, no bespoke jargon, no tortuous subtitles like "Gaia's B.O.U.N.T.Y." or "Hyperion's Wild Rumpus" - just the steadying prospect of a titanic quest that, who knows, may involve actual titans. The action-RPG beneath the moniker appears similarly straightforward: it's about following a plot thread through a mythological world in top-down view, smashing Ancient Greek giga-crabs and the like to obtain shinier, pointier varieties of gear. I'm sure I don't need to tell you that there's an endgame in which you farm monsters for crafting materials.
Like Pandora opening her box, but without the accompanying tidal wave of sickness, curses and death, THQ Nordic have released a new trailer that talks you though all of this in detail. Here it is...

entry.title: World Of Goo 2 review: an inventive return to goo with some flies in the ointment
entry.summary: The first World Of Goo was a cheerful parade of goopy engineering with a sense of never-ending novelty (well, never-ending for about four hours). Every level would introduce a new goo type or a twist on the basic bridge-building puzzle that challenged you to get a gaggle of gurgling balls to the nearest pipe. World Of Goo 2 pursues that sense of novelty with just as much twitchy eagerness as its predecessor, throwing new toys and goos at the player in an effort to keep you on your sludge-coated toes. That pursuit doesn't always result in pleasing new levels, though. There is a "hit and miss" feeling to things this time around. But those hits are hits. For anyone who has spent the last 16 years yearning for more sticky structure-building: I hope you like comically unpredictable fluids. Read more

The poems I've engaged with the most are those read out during wedding ceremonies, those that pop-up before the start of a horror game, or The Tiger by 6-year old Nael that occasionally pops up as I'm doomscrolling. But thanks to the multiplayer web game "fridge poetry", where you drag words to create poems, I might become a day-to-day poem guy. Going off my first effort, I don't think many will appreciate my career switch. Read more

entry.title: Apex Legends shelves plans to only charge real money for battle passes, following backlash
entry.summary: Apex Legends developers Respawn Entertainment have announced that poorly-received plans to overhaul the battle royale's Premium Battle Pass will be partially walked back. Most crucially, the new passes – set to launch alongside the upcoming Season 22 in August – will no longer be sold exclusively for real-world cash; as with previous BPs, players will still be able to buy them with accumulated in-game currency. entry.title: Grit And Valor 1949 is a real-time Into The Breach, or at least vaguely similar enough that I can squeeze a more popular game in this headline
entry.summary: Grit And Valor 1949 certainly evokes the tactics of Into The Breach, with its stompy machinery and floating tile battlegrounds. But, despite all appearances, this one isn’t actually turn-based at all. A tiley, tiny real time strategy then? Aye, and one that’s actually pretty frantic as it happens. Missions are snappy, intense skirmishes. You’ll fight off waves while trying to protect your useless, freeloading command vehicle. This threat, combined with on-the-fly tactical consider-me-do's like utilising cover and keeping rock-paper-scissors matchups in your favour ends up spawning something quite distinct. Please, do stomp on, preferably with less hypens for all our sakes. Read more

entry.title: You can now look forward to spending your weekend playing huge Fallout 4 mod Fallout: London
entry.summary: Update: Oh, hey. It's out now. Fallout: London, the massive fan-made Fallout 4 mod set in Poundland Prime (No Elephants, Some Castles, Canary Wharfare) has finally got a release date. Happy days, it’s actually today, Thursday 25th July. The news comes from Inverse, who’ve sent their dear alsatian companions sniffing around the mod’s Discord. Yesterday, Team FOLON lead Dean Carter shared the song I Just Can't Wait (For Tomorrow) then, when sniffed at harder, confirmed that the 'Tomorrow' part meant tomorrow (as in, today), "Unless nuclear war happens." entry.title: Kunitsu-Gami: Path Of The Goddess review: a totally fine take on tower defence
entry.summary: Capcom's turned back the clock with Kunitsu-Gami: Path Of The Goddess, bringing to us an action RPG tower defence hybrid that's very 2000s and very welcome in this age of open world, live service-ness. And for some, it'll deliver what's needed: a fairly good time. A time marked by a loop that does hack 'n slash, management, and a dash of base repairs to an average degree. For me, though, and possibly many others, I simply don't think this mix ever truly captures what makes even the simplest of tower defence games so captivating. Read more
